translation.en: [narrator] From the late '80s onward,
hip-hop was dominated by two regions,
translation.ko: 힙합은 두 지역이 꽉 쥐고 있었습니다

translation.en: the East and the West.
[narrator] But Atlanta's rise in the mid '90s
marked the start of a new chapter in hip-hop.
A power shift to the South
that was rooted in regional pride,
and shaped by indigenous influences.
Because, all across the South,
free from preconceptions of what hip-hop could be or should be,
DJs, MCS and producers were creating the future of hip-hop...
translation.ko: 디제이와 MC, 프로듀서들이 힙합의 미래를 일궜습니다

translation.en: including here: New Orleans.
New Orleans is a musical place, it's a magical place
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스는 음악적인 곳이죠 음악가에 대해 논할 때

translation.en: when you talk about musicians.
You can find one on every corner.
translation.ko: 길을 가면 늘 음악하는 사람이 보이죠

translation.en: [male] You have so much mixture of different types of music in the city.
translation.ko: 이곳은 서로 다른 음악이 뒤섞여 있는 곳이에요

translation.en: We call it "gumbo." You put a lot of different flavors in it, man,
translation.ko: 이걸 우리는 '검보'라고 하는데 맛이 여러 가지가 들어가 있죠

translation.en: and you get one big pot out of it.
[DJ Jubilee] It makes New Orleans unique, and people just wanna be a part of it.
translation.ko: 이게 뉴올리언스의 특색이에요 모두가 참여하려고 하죠

translation.en: [narrator] As the birthplace of jazz and the home of Mardi Gras,
NOLA was bound to touch hip-hop.
translation.ko: 힙합에도 영향을 주는 건 시간 문제였어요

translation.en: This is a city where music underscores everything.
Because in New Orleans, there's music in life,
and there's music in death.
[Charlie] It's important to understand
that New Orleans is the most Africanized city in America.
translation.ko: 가장 아프리카화된 곳이라는 점을 잘 이해할 필요가 있어요

translation.en: Because the French were very lax with the slaves,
translation.ko: 프랑스인들은 노예에게 너무 가혹하게 하지 않아서

translation.en: the Africans who were brought here
translation.ko: 이곳으로 오게 된 흑인들이 아프리카 문화를

translation.en: were able to retain a lot of African culture.
translation.ko: 잘 유지할 수 있는 기회가 됐어요

translation.en: In African culture, we don't look at death as "the end,"
translation.ko: 아프리카 문화에서는 죽음을 끝이라 생각하지 않죠

translation.en: we look at it as the next phase,
and you're supposed to celebrate that.
[Charlie] "Second line" is based on a New Orleans jazz funeral,
translation.ko: '두 번째 줄'이 뉴올리언스의 재즈 장례식에서 비롯된 거예요

translation.en: where you have the band leading the family down to the grave site.
That's the first line, is the family and the band,
translation.ko: 첫 번째 가는 사람들이 보통 유가족과 밴드죠

translation.en: and it's very somber.
And, on the way back,
whoever else joins in,
that becomes the second line
translation.ko: 이렇게 두 번째 줄이 만들어지는 거죠

translation.en: and it's really a party.
The second line is like a magnet.
You draw all kinds of people in and they all walk in the streets together,
translation.ko: 정말 다양한 사람들이 길을 가면서 하나가 돼요

translation.en: like, in one big ol' pile.
[DJ Jubilee] It's how we end off a party, with a great second line, baby.
translation.ko: 이게 두 번째 줄에서 우리가 파티하는 방식이죠

translation.en: -[interviewer] That's it. -[DJ Jubilee] Oh. Watch out, y'all.
[male] If you go to the second line, as the band's playing,
translation.ko: 두 번째 줄로 가면 밴드 연주에 맞춰

translation.en: a couple of people will pick up something and play with them.
translation.ko: 사람들이 손에 잡히는 걸로 연주를 따라해요

translation.en: I don't care if it's a bottle or a stick,
a screwdriver hitting on a stop sign,
they will find something just to be part of what the band's doing.
translation.ko: 무엇이든 찾아서 밴드 연주에 모두가 참여해요

translation.en: New Orleans is just related to music,
and it's just our DNA.
[Mia X] We move to a different beat in New Orleans.
The influence of the Mardi Gras Indians,
and the second line bands are in us every time we get ready to write a rhyme.
translation.ko: 장례식 행렬에서 항상 라임을 찾을 수 있죠

translation.en: What it is, is a lot of chanting.
[interviewer] Call and response is a big part of it, right?
translation.ko: 부르면 답하는 형식이 가장 많이 보여요, 알죠?

translation.en: [female] I love it. I'm about to show you what it is.
Alright.
When I say "Cheeky," you say "Blakk."
-I'm Cheeky. -Blakk.
-I'm Cheeky. -Blakk.
-We rockin', we rollin' with Cheeky. -Blakk.
-You movin', you groovin' with Cheeky. -Blakk.
I love the way you really sing it with Cheeky.
-Blakk. -Twerk up.
-I forgot that one already. -Twerk something.
Something... I already forgot it.
It all connects: the Mardi Gras Indians, the second line sound.
translation.ko: 마디 그라와 행렬 두 번째 줄 모두를 잇는 거예요

translation.en: You heard all that good stuff like that at block parties.
translation.ko: 이미 블록 파티에서 다 들어본 거잖아요

translation.en: And it's the beat.
It's the beat that gets the feet moving,
and the hands clapping, and the people jumping.
translation.ko: 손뼉 치고 점프하게 하는 그 비트 말이에요

translation.en: On that note, block parties here,
were they a big thing when you were growing up?
translation.ko: 어렸을 때 블록 파티가 자주 있었나요?

translation.en: Oh, most definitely.
You say they got a block party here, everybody meeting at that location.
translation.ko: 블락 파티를 한다고 하면 거기에 사람들이 다 모였어요

translation.en: You got guys on motorbikes,
you got girls in their high shorts.
Wherever the girls go, the fellas will follow.
[Mia X] Block parties really used to be in the projects, you know.
translation.ko: 블록 파티는 원래 빈민가에서 했던 건데

translation.en: We used to call it the DJ,
and that's how a lot of DJs made a name for themselves.
translation.ko: 그렇게 많은 디제이들이 이름을 알리게 된 거예요

translation.en: You know, the late, great Sabu,
he was, like, one of the first mobile DJs we had in New Orleans.
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스에서 가장 초창기 디제이 중에 한 명이었어요

translation.en: He was, like, the record man, and he would pass on your block,
and he would play records, and, you know,
he gave block parties before block parties were block parties.
translation.ko: 그럼 파티가 시작하기도 전에 이미 파티가 시작한 셈이죠

translation.en: Then Sabu had a baby.
He was, like, a child prodigy.
He could do everything at a young age.
translation.ko: 그 어린 나이에 재능이 정말 많았어요

translation.en: I'm not surprised that he is one of the greatest producers in the game.
translation.ko: 가장 위대한 프로듀서 중에 하나로 성장한 게 놀랍지 않죠

translation.en: His love for music was just always there.
translation.ko: 그의 음악에 대한 사랑은 변함 없었으니까요

translation.en: He was always trying to push the envelope.
[narrator] DJ Sabu rocked block parties across New Orleans,
translation.ko: 사부는 뉴올리언스 전역에서 블록 파티를 평정했는데

translation.en: but his biggest legacy was right at home.
translation.ko: 사실상 제일 위대한 업적은 집에서 탄생했습니다

translation.en: Because, while Sabu was working the turntables,
his son was watching and listening,
soaking up the game and learning the craft.
And, he'd apply all his knowledge
to set the tone for the sound of NOLA hip-hop.
translation.ko: 근간을 만드는 데 그런 지식을 모두 쏟아부었죠

translation.en: My dad, Sabu, was a street DJ in New Orleans,
translation.ko: 제 아버지 사부는 뉴올리언스의 스트리트 디제이셨죠

translation.en: and his performances were crazy.
I remember my dad used to come home with 'DJ of the Year' trophies.
translation.ko: '올해의 디제이상'을 들고 집에 오시던 게 기억이 나요

translation.en: Early on, my dad did block parties.
translation.ko: 초창기에 아버지는 블록 파티를 주로 하셨죠

translation.en: I just remember my dad back-spinning Chic, "Good Times."
translation.ko: 시크의 '굿 타임'으로 백 스피닝 하시는 게 기억나죠

translation.en: I had never heard the song before,
but I was just like, "Whatever the fuck that is,
I need to learn how to do that."
That was the defining moment. That record.
translation.ko: 그때가 결정적인 순간이었어요 그 음반 말이에요

translation.en: It was life-changing.
I practiced 24/7, all day,
get on my mom's nerves, my dad's nerves.
He a DJ, but he still going,
"Turn that shit off."
[Mannie Fresh] I started DJing block parties.
Now, at the time, Miami bass had started jumping off.
translation.ko: 그때는 마이애미 베이스가 유행하기 시작할 때예요

translation.en: I noticed that everybody in New Orleans loves 808 beats.
I started bringing my 808 drum machine to the gigs, and that caught on.
translation.ko: 808 드럼 머신을 공연장에 가져가곤 했는데 인기가 좋았죠

translation.en: Kids would be like,
"Hey, when you gonna play the drum machine?"
This is what people wanted me to do, more than DJing.
At the time, I was working at Allen Toussaint's Sea-Saint studio.
The guy in there was like,
"Do you know any rappers?"
And I'm like, "Yeah, I know this guy, Gregory D."
So they're just like, "If y'all wanna make a song,
y'all can do it,
but it's gotta kind of sound like something New Orleans."
translation.ko: 단 뉴올리언스 느낌이 나야 한다고 했죠

translation.en: This is somebody's idea of how I'm gonna merge hip-hop with jazz.
And, I'm automatically going,
"If I get a chance, I'm just gonna put some 808 drums in there."
translation.ko: 만약 기회가 있다면 808 드럼을 꼭 집어넣어야겠다고 생각했어요

translation.en: And I'm like, "It ain't gonna be no horns and all."
translation.ko: 호른 같은 악기도 빠질 수 없다 생각했죠

translation.en: I laid the beat down,
and I was like,
"What if I just tripled the snares and all of that?"
The drums started sounding like,
"Well, damn, that's like a New Orleans pattern."
It came from growing up here.
translation.ko: 나고 자란 곳에서 영향을 받은 거죠

translation.en: I just turned this... this 808 drum into the New Orleans second line
translation.ko: 808 드럼으로 뉴올리언스의 두 번째 행렬을 만든 거죠

translation.en: jazz drumming.
And so, Greg was like,
"I know how to make it traditional New Orleans buck jump."
translation.ko: 정통 뉴올리언스 느낌을 어떻게 만드는지 안다며 '벅 점프'를 말했죠

translation.en: "Buck jump" is pretty much a dance in New Orleans.
translation.ko: 벅 점프는 뉴올리언스 사람들의 춤 중 하나예요

translation.en: It's what you do when you second line.
translation.ko: 두 번째 행렬에서 주로 하는 춤이죠

translation.en: It was like, "Okay, this is what classic New Orleans wanna hear."
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스 사람들이라면 듣고 싶어하는 음악이다 싶었어요

translation.en: They like, "Yeah, say something about buck jumping, about unity,
translation.ko: 벅 점핑, 통합 등에 대해 말하고

translation.en: keep everybody together or whatever."
So, that's how this song came.
♪ Buck jump time ♪ ♪ That Melpomene ♪
translation.ko: "벅 점프 타임, 그레고리 디와 매니 프레시 (1989)"

translation.en: [male] When I did "Buck Jump"-- Let me explain this to you.
The thing about New Orleans that's so different...
You know how some people will claim the Eastside or the Westside?
They claim "wards" down here.
Third Ward, Fourth Ward, Fifth Ward, Sixth Ward, Seventh Ward, Eighth Ward.
I took the chance. I'm like, "You know what?
I'm gonna talk about every project and every ward in New Orleans,
and I'm gonna make these motherfuckers lose their motherfucking mind
by claiming their goddamn wards."
The song was huge, but every time I played the song,
translation.ko: 그 곡은 대단했어요 하지만 노래를 할 때마다

translation.en: a fight would start.
"Buck jump time! That Caliope. Buck jump time! That--"
translation.ko: '벅 점프 타임, 캘리오프 벅 점프 타임...'

translation.en: And the next minute, boom, everybody would be fighting.
[Mannie Fresh] But, when you played this at a party,
some preppy kids, they got off the dancefloor.
translation.ko: 몇몇 온순한 애들이 댄스 플로어를 떠났어요

translation.en: They be like, "Nah, I'm not messing with that."
Like, when that played, fights.
It's like a war call.
When this record comes on,
anybody that you have a problem with,
translation.ko: 뭔가 마음 속에 응어리가 있는 친구는

translation.en: when that song comes on, that's the cue to go looking for him.
translation.ko: 노래가 나오면 바로 싸우러 가는 거예요

translation.en: "Now, we 'bout to handle this right now."
♪ That Third Ward kicking it? Hell yeah! ♪ ♪ That Fifth Ward kicking it? Hell yeah! ♪ ♪ That Seventh Ward kicking it? Hell yeah! ♪
They used to go off, man. This ward's going against this ward.
translation.ko: 그렇게 악에 받쳐 싸워요 이 구역에서 저 구역한테

translation.en: This ward's going against that ward.
We did the record for togetherness.
But, we opened up a door
that everybody saw that, "You know what? this shit can happen down here."
translation.ko: 안 좋은 일이 생길 수 있는 걸 모두가 보게 된 거예요

translation.en: [narrator] "Buck Jump Time" was a breakthrough for NOLA's hip-hop scene,
bridging the gap between New York-style hip-hop
and New Orleans' traditional rhythms and chants.
translation.ko: 정통 리듬과 노래의 사이를 이은 겁니다

translation.en: That was a logical evolution for hip-hop in The Crescent City,
translation.ko: 일명 '크레센트 시티'인 이곳에 혁명의 바람을 불러온 거죠

translation.en: But, sometimes hip-hop grows in unexpected ways,
translation.ko: 그런데 힙합은 가끔 예상치 못한 방향으로 발전합니다

translation.en: and for NOLA,
serendipity would come in the form of an unknown record
translation.ko: 별로 유명하지 않았던 랩 그룹의 한 곡으로 인해

translation.en: from an unsung rap group.
"Triggerman" was just this popular song
that I started spinning.
It was from New York.
A shoutout to The Showboys.
The real name of the song was "Drag Rap,"
but we started calling it "Triggerman"
because there's one of the parts in the song
where he says something about "Triggerman."
The drums was hard, and it had these crazy breaks
translation.ko: 드럼 사운드가 강렬해요 스내어로 끊어지는 소시를

translation.en: where the snares went...
Then, it would break down into this cool 808 beat.
[Mannie Fresh] This pivotal beat changes the city.
Everybody is jamming to it, but there's no words to it.
translation.ko: 다들 곡을 틀기는 하는데 가사는 없었어요

translation.en: My dad is still DJing, right?
My dad was like,
"Hey, there's this dude, T.T. Tucker, and DJ Irv.
They'll come to these little spots that I'm doing,
translation.ko: 내가 있는 곳에 와서 공연 신나게 하라고

translation.en: holes in the wall, and I'll just let them rock.
translation.ko: 내가 있는 곳에 와서 공연 신나게 하라고 할 생각이야'라고 하셨죠

translation.en: They jamming off some of the beats that, you know, like, you playing."
translation.ko: 제가 트는 비트로 공연할 거라고 하시더군요

translation.en: [male] At Ghost Town club,
DJ Irv is just doing cuts over "Triggerman,"
and Tucker just gets up there and starts chanting,
"Where Dey At? Where Dey At? Where Dey At?"
And, it was just chants,
call and response.
Whenever that record came on,
the "Where Dey Ats," you knew, this is the Seventh Ward, where they at.
You throw up the sevens, you know, "Where Dey At?
You know, that started the whole movement in New Orleans.
It was recorded horrible, trashy sounding,
but it was just so in your face.
What I didn't know was this was the start of bounce music.
translation.ko: 그게 바운스 음악의 시작인지는 그땐 알지 못했어요

translation.en: [narrator] DJ Irv's "Where Dey At?" was a lo-fi underground smash
that introduced NOLA to the infectious "Triggerman" sample,
translation.ko: '트리거맨' 샘플링 대유행으로 몰고 간 언더 음악이었어요

translation.en: and the city couldn't get enough of it.
translation.ko: 도시 전체가 그 비트에 미쳐 있었죠

translation.en: Because, somewhere between the booming 808s and staccato percussion,
the city found more than a special record.
translation.ko: 이 특별한 곡이 탄생했고 그보다도 바운스 음악을

translation.en: They found bounce music.
translation.ko: 찾게 된 게 더 큰 발견이었습니다

translation.en: ♪ We got New Orleans in the house tonight ♪
[interviewer] Yes, sir.
[male] Hey, what's up, man? What's up?
[interviewer] Obviously, "Triggerman" was an important record
for the evolution of bounce music.
What did you think when you first heard that record?
translation.ko: 처음에 그 곡을 듣고 어떤 생각이 들던가요?

translation.en: Well, we always kind of had it in rotation, playing here.
translation.ko: 여기서 그 곡을 항상 반복해서 틀었죠

translation.en: I was the DJ.
It was really nothing but "Triggerman."
It was hours and hours of nothing but that one loop.
translation.ko: 몇 시간을 그 곡만 계속 트는 거예요

translation.en: And how did you hone your skills as far as getting on the mic
translation.ko: 그럼 마이크를 잡는 거나 사람들 참여를 이끌어내는 건

translation.en: and getting the crowd participation?
The girls who would come and used to...
You could win $500 for a pussy pop contest.
[laughing] Believe it or not.
When I got up on the mic, I'd just say anything to make you move.
translation.ko: 제가 마이크를 들었을 때 다들 춤을 추도록 유도했어요

translation.en: Ask you where you from, where you at,
tell a ho to put her back down, you know.
What I was trying to express was that this music here made everybody dance.
translation.ko: 제가 말하려는 건... 어쨌든 이 음악으로 다들 춤추게 했다는 거예요

translation.en: I'm just feeling what we were doing in these places.
[interviewer] That song, it was just so popular.
Beyond New Orleans, too. It was on Billboard, right?
[DJ Jimi] First six weeks, it went gold.
If you didn't play this record on your radio station,
you probably wasn't listening.
They had to play it.
♪ Do it baby, stick it baby Do it baby, stick it baby ♪ ♪ Do it baby, stick it Stick it baby do it ♪
[Charlie] DJ Jimi is the king of bounce.
I mean, it sort of starts with him, in my opinion.
translation.ko: 디제이 지미로부터 바운스가 시작된 것 같아요

translation.en: [Charlie] When you think about all the great bounce musicians,
most of them revolved around Jimi in some way.
translation.ko: 어떤 면에서 지미를 중심으로 활동을 했었죠

translation.en: I don't know who originally started it,
but DJ Jimi made bounce famous.
translation.ko: 하지만 디제이 지미가 바운스를 유명하게 만들었죠

translation.en: It was the first bounce record that left from the city to somewhere else.
translation.ko: 다른 곳에서도 유명해진 첫 번째 바운스 앨범이었어요

translation.en: [DJ Jubilee] DJ Jimi changed the whole scene, man.
translation.ko: 디제이 지미가 판도를 완전히 바꿔 놓았죠

translation.en: He sold a lot of albums, and he opened up the doors.
translation.ko: 앨범이 진짜 많이 팔렸어요 그가 새로운 문을 연 거죠

translation.en: That's when we knew he had our sound.
-And that inspired you? -[DJ Jubilee] That definitely inspired me.
translation.ko: - 그게 영감을 준 거네요? - 그렇죠, 영감을 줬죠

translation.en: When I put out "Do The Jubilee All," in 1993,
I did not know that it was gonna fly that way.
[DJ Jubilee singing "Jubilee All"] ♪ Do the Jubilee All ♪ ♪ Do the Jubi, do the Jubi Do the Jubilee All ♪
[Mannie Fresh] DJ Jubilee comes out with it.
Same song. Identical.
Which is cool in bounce.
If you don't understand it, you're like,
"Well, why does everything have the same damn beat?
translation.ko: 왜 다 똑같은 비트냐고 나왔던 곡 아니냐고

translation.en: "Didn't that song just go off?"
And, you know, but, that's just the way it is.
This city just takes something and runs with it.
[DJ Jubilee] My style came different, because I was the only one really dancing.
translation.ko: 제 스타일은 좀 달랐어요 저만 춤을 췄거든요

translation.en: I used to DJ at high school, and we started doing dances,
translation.ko: 고등학교 때 디제잉을 했어요 그리고 춤도 추고 그랬죠

translation.en: and challenges and stuff.
I came up with the first dance, "Do The Jubilee."
I was sliding side to side, "Do The Jubilee."
translation.ko: 양옆으로 왔다 갔다 하면서 '두 더 주빌리'

translation.en: Then, the next week, somebody came with another dance, the "Beanie Weenie."
translation.ko: 그 다음 주에는 누군가가 '비니 위니'라는 춤을 들고 나오죠

translation.en: Every week, we had a new, different dance.
So, now I got the hottest dance in the city.
I started getting smart, I'm like, "Hold up, we got all these dances,
translation.ko: 그러다 머리를 좀 썼어요 '전부 다른 춤들을 추는데

translation.en: and everybody doing so many different dances,
translation.ko: 이걸 한 데 모아서 노래로 만들면

translation.en: let me put it on a song."
[Big Freedia] Every song that he made, he made you dance with the song.
translation.ko: 그가 만든 곡은 전부 사람들이 춤을 추게 만들었죠

translation.en: It was like Simon Says.
Jubilee was our Simon Says of the bounce,
translation.ko: 주빌리가 바운스 음악에서는 그 놀이와 같았죠

translation.en: and if he said "Do the beanie weenie,"
you backing it up and doing the beanie weenie.
If he said "Do the Eldon DeLloyd," you do the Eldon DeLloyd.
translation.ko: '엘든 드로이드를 보여줘'라고 하면 그걸 추는 거고요

translation.en: They used to have girls flipping, you know, hands on the ground,
translation.ko: 그럼 여자들이 팔을 땅에 짚고 물구나무를 서서

translation.en: and their feet on the wall and, like, twerking.
translation.ko: 다리를 벽에 붙이고 트월킹을 하는 거죠

translation.en: And I'm like, "Holy shit. I wanna do that."
[interviewer] Many people say that's the first time they heard "twerk" on a record.
translation.ko: 처음 트월킹이란 게 곡에 쓰인 게 그때라고들 해요

translation.en: [DJ Jubilee] The girl's shaking it in front of us, right?
They took the word "work," and put a "T" on it, saying,
"They be twerking it!"
That's how we joke. "Twerking it."
That's another signature of New Orleans. You gotta deal with it.
♪ Shake baby, shake baby, shake, shake, shake baby ♪
[DJ Jubiee] Back then, when we started twerking it, it was new.
translation.ko: 트월킹이 시작될 즈음 그건 전혀 새로운 거였죠

translation.en: [DJ Jubiee] We done shook on top of rooftops, cars, taxis, buses.
translation.ko: 옥상, 자동차, 택시, 버스 위 어디에서든지 흔들었어요

translation.en: [DJ Jubiee] We shook it at second line funerals.
translation.ko: 옥상, 자동차, 택시, 버스 위 어디에서든지 흔들었어요 장례식 두 번째 행렬에서도요

translation.en: We the best twerkers in the country.
If you wanna see some real shaking going on, shaking is in New Orleans.
translation.ko: 진짜로 흔드는 게 뭔지 보고 싶으면 뉴올리언스를 봐야 해요

translation.en: [Katey Red] It's music, I guess you can just have fun with.
translation.ko: 음악과 함께면 좋은 시간을 보낼 수 있죠

translation.en: And, like, growing up in New Orleans,
you hear the music, you know, coming up as a child,
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스에서 살면 어릴 때부터 음악을 들으며 자라죠

translation.en: like, one, two, three years old, like, your parents gonna try to,
translation.ko: 한두 살 때부터 부모가 애들한테 이러죠

translation.en: "You better do it! Bend over! Shake!"
You know, they, like, teach you how to do it.
[female] You know, you play, like "Triggerman," the DJ hollering,
"Okay, everybody get on the wall."
You know, you get on the wall.
"Get on the table," you know.
"Get on the chair. Raise your leg up in the air."
"Bend over, touch, put that hump in your back."
You know, if you don't feel it when the music playing,
translation.ko: 음악 틀었을 때 그 느낌을 모르면

translation.en: you'll never get it.
[Mia X] First, it was Jimi, then it was Jubilee, then it was me.
translation.ko: 처음에는 지미, 그 다음 주빌리 그 다음은 저였어요

translation.en: I was one of the first girls to put a bounce record out.
translation.ko: 바운스를 세상에 내놓은 여자들 중에 하나가 저죠

translation.en: I just didn't like what the boys were saying.
You know, "Suck a nigga dick" and this.
So, once I didn't like what they were saying,
and the other girls agreed that they didn't like what they was sayin',
and they put their two cents in it,
and before you know it, as a guy would drop, a girl would drop.
translation.ko: 남자들도 앨범 내는데 여자들도 앨범 내죠

translation.en: [Charles] Bounce was the dominant form of hip-hop in New Orleans.
translation.ko: 바운스는 뉴올리언스에서 가장 지배적인 힙합 장르죠

translation.en: If you weren't doing bounce,
you had a hard time, you know,
finding a big, mass audience in this city. It was...
It was that powerful.
[KLC] It was to a point where it didn't matter who was on the record,
translation.ko: 실제로 어떤 음반인지는 크게 중요하지 않고

translation.en: that "Triggerman" beat alone gave you an advantage to rock the crowd.
translation.ko: '트리거맨' 비트 하나로도 관중을 끄는 힘이 있었던 거죠

translation.en: All you had to do was just say the right shit, and don't fuck up.
translation.ko: 그냥 제대로 된 가사로 절지만 않으면 되죠

translation.en: [male] Bounce music became our own thing because we started feeling like,
translation.ko: '다른 지역에서는 어떤 게 인기가 있는지 몰라도

translation.en: "We don't care what the rest of the world doing,
we're gonna do what we do."
We didn't care how big you were in the world.
translation.ko: 다른 데에서 얼마나 인기 있는지는 상관없어요

translation.en: When you come to our city, it's us.
We were just as big, bigger than you.
translation.ko: - 우리가 있지 - 누구든 우리가... 우리보다 잘할 수 없죠

translation.en: We were cocky, man. [laughing]
Super cocky.
[Big Freedia] It's something that people can get into, and have fun,
translation.ko: 사람들이 흠뻑 빠져서 즐길 수 있고

translation.en: and not think about their problems at the time.
This is the music that we make through our everyday struggle.
translation.ko: 매일 전쟁 같은 삶 속에서 만들어낸 음악이에요

translation.en: [narrator] The energetic, party-oriented tempo of bounce gave NOLA a signature sound
that was rooted in the city's rich jazz and second line tradition.
translation.ko: 파티에 특화되었는데 이곳 재즈와 두 번째 행렬이 그 근원이었죠

translation.en: It also gave the city a release...
...because, throughout the '90s,
the reality of black life in New Orleans was entirely different.
NOLA was besieged by drugs and violence,
translation.ko: 약물과 범죄로 들끓던 곳으로 미국에서 가장 높은

translation.en: with the highest homicide rates in America.
This was the other side of New Orleans,
but you wouldn't find it on a bounce record.
translation.ko: 바운스 음악에서는 그런 면을 찾을 수 없죠

translation.en: NOLA needed a different outlet,
and it would be a shrewd hustler from NOLA's Third Ward
translation.ko: 이런 상황을 잘 간파했던 3 구역 출신의 아티스트가 있었죠

translation.en: who would bring this reality to the world.
translation.ko: 그는 현실을 바깥 세상에 알리게 됩니다

translation.en: [Master P] These little kids ain't even five or six years old.
translation.ko: "노 리미트 레코드" 이 아이들은 대여섯 살쯤 되는데

translation.en: They done seen murders right there, on the spot.
translation.ko: 이미 살인 현장을 목격했죠 바로 그 자리에서요

translation.en: You know, I seen a murder at four years old right here.
translation.ko: 저도 네 살 때 이미 목격했어요

translation.en: [Master P] I grew up in Third Ward, Caliope Projects.
At the time,
it was one of the most dangerous places in the world to live.
translation.ko: 세계에서 가장 위험한 지역 중 하나로 꼽히던 곳이었어요

translation.en: Most of the crimes that happened in New Orleans,
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스에서 일어난 범죄 중 절반 정도는

translation.en: probably half of it happened in the Caliope Projects.
This is for real.
[male] The City of New Orleans and the hoods been at war since we were kids.
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스는 저희가 어릴 때부터 전쟁터와도 같았어요

translation.en: Yeah, I was in the military, I went to Desert Storm.
translation.ko: 저도 군인이었고 데저트 스톰 작전에도 투입됐는데

translation.en: What was the difference?
Only thing, they just had bigger guns and missiles.
translation.ko: 단지 더 큰 총과 미사일을 가진 것뿐이었어요

translation.en: [reporter] New Orleans has a record of homicides this year.
It has by far the highest murder rate of any big city in the nation.
translation.ko: 미국의 대도시 중 가장 높은 살인율을 기록하고 있습니다

translation.en: Five times the number of murders in cities of comparable size.
translation.ko: 비슷한 규모의 도시 살인율의 다섯 배에 해당합니다

translation.en: [Master P] You know, me and brother Kevin,
we used to sit in the projects and say,
"Who gonna die first?"
If you lived to be 19, you a OG in the projects.
translation.ko: 열아홉 살까지 살면 나이가 든 축에 속하죠

translation.en: That was our magic number, man. If we could live to be 19,
translation.ko: 열아홉이 일종의 마법의 숫자 같은 거였어요

translation.en: you know, we'd made it.
And, I mean, he died at that age.
And, that just-- that tore something out of my heart.
You know, when I watched my mom, her whole world turned upside down,
translation.ko: 엄마를 지켜보면서 세상이 무너지는 것 같았죠

translation.en: and I'm like, "I don't wanna keep putting her through this.
translation.ko: '엄마를 이렇게 계속 힘들게 할 수 없으니

translation.en: I have to do something better with my life."
That's what really made me go hard with the music.
translation.ko: 그게 음악을 열심히 하게 한 원동력이었죠

translation.en: You know, I named my company "No Limit,"
because there's gonna be no limit to my success,
translation.ko: 왜냐면 제 성공에 한계는 없을 거니까요

translation.en: and I named myself "Master P"
because I said I'm gonna master whatever I do.
I was listening to Ice-T, "Colors."
That music did something for me.
You know, hearing the bounce music, it was a lot of party music,
translation.ko: 바운스 음악을 듣는데 이건 파티 음악이잖아요

translation.en: which was a good sound for New Orleans,
but I felt like we were missing something, you know?
translation.ko: 그런데 뭔가 빠진 게 있는 듯 했어요

translation.en: Seeing so many people die young,
translation.ko: 너무나 많은 청년들이 죽어가는 걸 보고

translation.en: seeing the crime, seeing the poverty.
You know, it just poured out of me.
I was able to tell my story.
[Master P] I'm just talking about what I see.
translation.ko: 제가 본 걸 그대로 가사에 넣었어요

translation.en: I mean, look around.
You see a bunch of mansions around here?
-Do you? -No.
Okay. Well, that's reality.
That's what I'm talking about.
[Master P] I built No Limit on $10,000.
I put up my own posters. I went to every hood.
I started taking my van, and going from hood to hood,
selling my CDs.
That's the whole thing.
I started selling it out of the trunk.
translation.ko: 말 그대로 차 트렁크에서 음반을 판 거죠

translation.en: I mean, we would be in DC, and here's the thing,
translation.ko: DC에 간다는 게 어떤 의미가 있냐면요

translation.en: we weren't supposed to be in DC.
translation.ko: 원래 거기에는 가면 안 되는 거예요

translation.en: That's like somebody going into Compton or whatever.
We were just so about hustling, we didn't care about the dangers.
translation.ko: 우리는 뭐든 열심히 했어요 위험 따위는 상관 안 했죠

translation.en: It's all we have, so we here.
And people were like,
"Y'all crazy enough to come in the neighborhood,
you know what? Gimme the CD."
[Gregory D] No Limit, that wasn't no, you know, no bounce shit.
translation.ko: 노 리미트의 음악은 바운스 음악은 아니었어요

translation.en: You could hear a hard life in that music,
but that's the way of life in New Orleans.
We gutter.
We gutter, bro. We gutter. We so goddamn gutter.
And the street cats, they wanna hear what they can relate to.
translation.ko: 갱들도 자신들이 공감할 음악을 듣고 싶어 했어요

translation.en: [Ricky B] Master P, when he hit the scene,
everybody was like, "Okay,"
but it wasn't that New Orleans sound.
So, we had to kind of learn,
"Okay, what's going on with No Limit?"
translation.ko: 뭘 하는지 주의 깊게 보게 됐죠

translation.en: [female] A lot of people didn't like his music in the beginning, right?
translation.ko: 처음에는 많은 사람들이 그의 음악을 안 좋아했어요

translation.en: Bitches all used to be throwing that man's fucking CDs back at him.
I remember that.
It seemed when Master P started dominating outskirts,
translation.ko: 마스터 P가 교외에서 이름을 알리게 되면서

translation.en: then New Orleans was like,
"Master P!"
New Orleans is, like, an ass-kissing city.
They gonna like you after the fact.
I remember buying a CD and a cassette from Percy Miller
translation.ko: 퍼시 밀러에게서 CD와 카세트 테이프를 샀었죠

translation.en: before I knew him or even worked with him,
translation.ko: 그를 알게 되고 같이 일하기도 전의 일이었어요

translation.en: because I felt like,
"I'm gonna support this dude, man. He out here selling his own stuff."
translation.ko: 그가 음반을 직접 파는 걸 보고 그를 밀어줘야겠다 생각했어요

translation.en: I'll never forget this, because he had his socks way up to here,
and I'm like, "Man, what's this dude doing with his socks way up to here?"
translation.ko: 대체 양말을 왜 저렇게 신고 있을까 궁금했죠

translation.en: I'm not clowning him, I'm just saying that he was confident in who he was,
translation.ko: 놀리는 건 아닌데 아무튼 자신감이 대단했어요

translation.en: and I just thought that was dope.
I was different, you know.
It might give you a slow start,
but being different is going to carry you a long way.
translation.ko: 개성이 있다는 건 오래갈 수 있다는 의미죠

translation.en: [Master P] We got a whole different plan.
They can't stop us, because, eventually, we gonna leak in.
translation.ko: 우리를 막을 수 없어 왜냐면 우리는 스며들 거니까...

translation.en: P wanted to be respected as a major label,
translation.ko: 마스터 P는 자신의 회사를 대형 회사로 키우길 원했죠

translation.en: which meant that you had to put out more records.
translation.ko: 그러니까 더 많은 앨범을 내야만 했어요

translation.en: He scoured the city,
and he did what I like to call "corporate raiding."
He raided every label
and got their top artists.
[Mia X] Master P came to my house, and he just explained to me
translation.ko: 마스터 P가 저희 집에 찾아왔을 때 노 리미트의 계획을

translation.en: what his plans were for No Limit.
And, he was like,
"It's an independent label,
but they're gonna look at it like a major label.
translation.ko: 결국에는 주요 레이블로 인식될 거다'라고 했죠

translation.en: I'm gonna make history,
and it's gonna be big,
and I want you to be a part of it."
It was something about the way he said it, I could feel it.
translation.ko: 마스터 P의 말에서 저는 진심을 느낄 수 있었어요

translation.en: I knew that he was gonna do what he said he was gonna do.
[KLC] P got the greatest MCs from the city.
He had Mystikal, Soulja Slim.
Everybody came there.
It was just, like, open house to whoever wanna rap,
translation.ko: 랩을 하고 싶은 사람한테 활짝 열린 곳이었어요

translation.en: and then you had five people doing beats for you.
Beats By The Pound.
So, as soon as he finished a song, we pulling up the next.
translation.ko: 곡을 하나 마치고 나면 바로 다음 곡 작업을 했어요

translation.en: Relentless hustle.
No Limit was like a big-ass freestyle.
P fed off of everybody.
This is how it all formed
for No Limit to become what it is.
All of us being together in the studio, 24/7,
you know, songs were just cranking out of us.
I felt like I had the best of the best for us making music.
translation.ko: 최고 중의 최고만을 모아서 음악을 만들었죠

translation.en: So, when I heard the beat for "Make 'Em Say Uhh!",
I felt like I needed to put this city on the map.
[Fiend] "Make 'Em Say Uhh!", man.
He turned around and said, "Look, this is gonna be a big song,
translation.ko: 마스터 P는 이 곡이 뜰 거라고 했어요

translation.en: a big-ass song,
and everybody gonna wanna get on here.
translation.ko: 누구든 이 곡에 참여해도 된다고 했죠

translation.en: Whoever ready with their verse is getting on here,
and that's gonna be the order."
I remember writing on the wall, piece of paper, I was ready.
translation.ko: 벽에 종이를 대고 바로 가사를 적었어요

translation.en: "A'ight, Fiend, you go ahead," you know.
He didn't ask to hear it.
I went up in there,
"Fiend exercising his right of exorcism, bustin' out the Expedition"
translation.ko: '피엔드의 악령 쫓을 권리 엑스페디션을 타며 달려'

translation.en: [Fiend] No Limit Records, it was all these artists, producers,
all sharing this type of energy,
moving as one unit.
And, it just became something to be reckoned with, man.
translation.ko: 그러면서 무시할 수 없는 존재로 떠오르게 됐죠

translation.en: ♪ Make ‘em say uhh, uhh ♪
[KLC] "Make 'Em Say Uhh!" was our first big mainstream record.
translation.ko: 그 음반이 저희의 첫 번째 히트 음반이었어요

translation.en: That was the first record that went everywhere.
translation.ko: 어디서든 그 곡을 들을 수 있었어요

translation.en: You know, that was all your work,
you know, everything that you put into this,
here's your trophy for it.
Y'all don't understand. 1998, we put out 26 albums.
They were like, "How did y'all do this shit?
How in the fuck y'all do it?"
In '98, things were just going at a crazy pace.
I'd imagine that time would be a bit of a blur,
translation.ko: 1998년에 많은 것들이 갑작스럽게 변했잖아요 그때 기억이 선명하진 않겠지만 그래도

translation.en: but what do you remember of the process?
It was like a factory, you know.
It was like a factory, but, we had fun doing it.
translation.ko: 그렇긴 하지만 다들 곡 작업을 즐겼죠

translation.en: Albums were getting done quick.
You had five producers.
I go to you, I don't even get time to listen to it.
translation.ko: 한 명 한 명 다 들을 시간도 없었어요

translation.en: Now I go in the next room to him,
and keep coming back around 'til my album was done.
translation.ko: 앨범이 끝날 때까지 왔다 갔다 했어요

translation.en: [Mia X] I wrote and recorded 16 songs in 10 days,
translation.ko: 열흘 만에 열여섯 개의 곡을 쓰고 녹음까지 했어요

translation.en: and it came out number two in the Top 200,
and the only person that was on top of me was Céline Dion.
translation.ko: 제 위에 있던 사람이 단 한 명, 셀린 디온이었어요

translation.en: Now, how could you be mad at that? That's Céline Dion!
You know, I remember going to KLC's house.
translation.ko: KLC의 집에 갔던 걸 아직 기억해요

translation.en: The wall was five, six, seven times longer than this wall.
translation.ko: 이 벽보다 다섯, 여섯 배나 긴 벽이었는데

translation.en: They had plaques as far as you could see.
The whole wall was filled with plaques.
Them boys did more in a year
than most record companies do in their whole tenure.
translation.ko: 노 리미트가 1년 안에 낸 앨범만큼 못 찍어냈을 거예요

translation.en: I love all y'all niggas, for real.
All you motherfuckers that kept it real with No Limit.
I made my motherfucking money the right way.
[Charles] This is the turning point for New Orleans music.
P, as an independent, had a distribution deal
translation.ko: 마스터 P는 독립 레이블로 판매 계약을 따냈어요

translation.en: which means that they are actually standalone labels
that have total control of their own music,
and they get the majority of the money.
That's unheard of.
They awakened a sleeping giant in Southern hip-hop,
translation.ko: 남부 힙합의 잠자는 거인을 깨운 거예요

translation.en: because labels looked at P and said,
"If he can do it, we can do it."
translation.ko: 우리도 할 수 있다'고 생각하기 시작했죠

translation.en: Me going up against the music industry independently,
translation.ko: 영혼을 팔면서 음악을 한 게 아니라

translation.en: without having to sell your soul,
and being an African-American kid from New Orleans is unheard of.
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스의 흑인 꼬마가 말이죠 전례가 없었어요

translation.en: Talk about hustle,
I am the best hustler
that ever came out of Louisiana, New Orleans, the South.
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스, 남부 통틀어서 가장 노력했다고 자부해요

translation.en: [narrator] Master P and No Limit put New Orleans on the map in hip-hop,
translation.ko: 마스터 P와 그의 레이블은 뉴올리언스를 힙합씬에 합류시켰죠

translation.en: but while No Limit's hardcore style sold major units,
translation.ko: 그들의 곡은 하드코어 스타일로 앨범이 많이 사랑을 받았지만

translation.en: their sound was still a departure for the city.
New Orleans was still ruled by bounce,
but in the duality of the city, there was an opportunity.
translation.ko: 하지만 도시의 이중성 속에 기회가 하나 있었습니다

translation.en: And NOLA had no shortage of hard-working hustlers,
translation.ko: 어려움 속에서도 노력하는 아티스트들이 넘쳐나는 곳이죠

translation.en: including a pair of brothers from the city's tough Magnolia Projects,
translation.ko: 매그놀리아 프로젝트 지역 출신 아티스트 형제가 있었는데

translation.en: who would follow Master P's blueprint for independent success.
translation.ko: 이들이 독자적인 성공을 향해 마스터 P의 족적을 따라갔죠

translation.en: [male] We the millennium.
We've come to take this game and bring it to me.
translation.ko: 우리가 이 게임을 가져가서 성공할 거예요

translation.en: We gonna be here. I ain't no fly-by-night nigga.
translation.ko: 우린 계속 남을 거예요 하룻밤으로 끝나지 않죠

translation.en: Gonna be here two years, three years.
I got this shit.
[Mannie Fresh] I met Baby and Slim.
I was DJing in the Caliope,
and that's way out of my area.
But every week, the drug dealers had me there,
translation.ko: 하지만 매주 마약상들이 저를 모셔 가려 했어요

translation.en: because they wanted to keep that crowd out there.
Baby and them were there.
He was just like, "I wanna make records
and I think you're the dude, you know, that could bring it to the next level."
translation.ko: 다음 단계로 성장하려면 당신이 필요하다'고 하더군요

translation.en: I think Baby could sell space heaters in hell.
This dude will give you a speech,
and y'all could be down by a hundred points,
and he can make your ass believe that you're going to win that game.
translation.ko: 이 친구랑 함께라면 뭐든 할 것처럼 믿게 되죠

translation.en: Now, at the time, they had an artist called Kilo G,
and I'm going, "That's cool, but bounce is popular right now.
Let's try a bounce record and see what happens."
translation.ko: 바운스 음반을 내보고 반응을 보자'고 했어요

translation.en: Well, I'd heard about these dudes from my dad, called U.N.L.V.
They were three little dudes who would just go around,
rapping off of breakbeats or whatever,
but they had a following.
You know, there were only, like, three different labels in New Orleans,
and they was one of them,
and they were trying to get their label off the ground,
translation.ko: 회사를 좀 더 키우고 싶어 했고

translation.en: and we weren't even in the studio.
We recorded our first album in Mannie Fresh's kitchen,
translation.ko: 그래서 첫 앨범을 매니 프레시의 부엌에서

translation.en: as a matter of fact.
Every album that we had done a lot of numbers, you know.
translation.ko: 저희가 낸 앨범은 반응이 정말 좋았어요

translation.en: We did real well with them.
We opened the doors for them to sign other artists,
translation.ko: 다른 아티스트들을 영입하기 위한 문을 열어주고

translation.en: added a little more revenue.
And, what we were doing differently,
we were actually using the bounce tracks,
but we were putting gangsta lyrics on top of it.
translation.ko: 그렇지만 갱스터 가사를 그 위에 얹었죠

translation.en: [M$. Tee] What was different about Cash Money was,
we were telling stories with our bounce.
We had the catchy beats or whatever,
but it was more of a reality bounce.
translation.ko: 거긴 현실감 있는 바운스 음악에 가까웠죠

translation.en: [interviewer] Baby and Slim, what do you remember of that relationship?
Like, did they have different roles in Cash Money?
translation.ko: 캐시 머니에서 다른 역할을 맡고 있었나요?

translation.en: What I can say about them, they knew how to pick talent.
translation.ko: 제가 말할 수 있는 하나는 인재를 볼 줄 안다는 거예요

translation.en: Oh, my god, bro, they have a gift.
Baby and Slim, they were always looking for new artists.
You know, we had U.N.L.V. for a long time,
translation.ko: UNLV가 활동한 지도 꽤 오래된 시점이어서

translation.en: but it was, you know, it was time for a new little era.
translation.ko: 새로운 시대를 열 시간이 찾아왔던 거죠

translation.en: We knew what time it was.
I think it was, it was, like, a part of Baby and Slim's strategy
to almost recreate a U.N.L.V.,
but also add more to the company.
translation.ko: 좀 더 회사에 새로운 걸 더하고 싶었죠

translation.en: [narrator] Cash Money's vision for reality bounce was a turning point for the label,
translation.ko: 현실을 반영한 바운스가 캐시 머니에 전환점이 됐습니다

translation.en: but they needed rappers to pull it off,
and who better than a prodigy of the bounce scene:
A gold-toothed rapper who got his start with DJ Jimi,
translation.ko: 디제이 지미와 커리어를 시작한 금이빨의 래퍼

translation.en: and went by the name of Juvenile.
-Glad you made it. -Thank you so much.
Let's do it.
[interviewer] So, why don't we just start at the beginning,
and tell me how you connected with DJ Jimi.
[Juvenile] I mean, I started off rapping at the block parties.
translation.ko: 저는 블록 파티에서 랩을 하면서 경력을 쌓았죠

translation.en: It was only, like, a couple of us who could actually walk up,
translation.ko: 오직 소수 몇 명만이 무대에 올라가

translation.en: grab the microphone, and just start running it.
translation.ko: 마이크를 잡고 공연을 할 수 있었죠

translation.en: And, shit, I was one of them. I was upper echelon.
Jimi got an opportunity to take me to the studio.
translation.ko: 지미가 저를 스튜디오에 데려갈 기회를 잡았고

translation.en: When I got in there, I realized I was gonna be the writer.
translation.ko: 제가 거기 갔을 때 곡을 쓸 거라는 걸 직감했죠

translation.en: You know, I thought I was going in there to do songs for myself.
translation.ko: 저를 위한 곡을 할 거라고 생각했었는데

translation.en: I wrote damn near every song on the album.
translation.ko: 앨범에 들어가는 거의 모든 곡을 쓴 거예요

translation.en: "Bounce (For The Juvenile),"
I did that just to put my name out there.
Like, it was a slick way of getting on his album.
translation.ko: 지미 앨범에 숟가락 얹으려고 머리를 좀 썼죠

translation.en: [Juvenile] The "Bounce (For The Juvenile)" song actually blew up.
It made record companies pay attention to the little cat in the background.
translation.ko: 뒷골목 고양이 같은 레이블에 다른 회사들이 집중하게 된 거죠

translation.en: You know what I'm saying, like, "Wait, hold up. So he wrote all that?"
I was actually at the bus stop on Canal Street.
translation.ko: 하루는 커널 가에 버스 정류장에 있었는데

translation.en: Baby and them pulled up on me, like
"Man, I wanna talk to you."
They picked me up from the bus stop, man, took me to the studio.
translation.ko: 저를 거기서 스튜디오까지 끌고 간 거죠

translation.en: I ain't never looked back.
[Mannie Fresh] Juvie was established,
but it's this other kid,
he's a prodigy, nuts, he can rap.
It's Lil Wayne.
Now, at the time, Lil Wayne is 11, 12, something like that.
translation.ko: 릴 웨인이 당시 대략 열한 살, 열두 살 정도였어요

translation.en: Magnolia Shorty, rest in peace,
she was like, "Hey, I know a little guy, Turk.
Nice on the mic."
She brings him in.
And BG, he's from Baby and them's block.
translation.ko: BG는 베이비 쪽 구역에서 온 친구인데

translation.en: So, now we got four solo dudes,
translation.ko: 이렇게 솔로 래퍼만 네 명이 된 거예요

translation.en: and I get this idea to say, like:
"Dude, this is what we gonna do.
To build everybody else's career off of this,
I'm gonna put y'all together
and become The Hot Boys.
It was almost like a boy band,
some thug boy band group.
It was the whole movement of, you know,
you want people to turn into this.
You want people to turn into, "I want to be like these dudes."
translation.ko: '나도 저렇게 되고 싶다'고 느끼게 만드는 거였죠

translation.en: [Juvenile] BG's straight gangster, straight street.
Wayne, real witty, clever with words.
translation.ko: 릴 웨인은 가사로 장난을 잘 치는 친구였고요

translation.en: Turk was the freak of the clique, and I'm the old dude.
translation.ko: 터크는 유별난 멤버였어요 저는 나이가 많았고요

translation.en: -[interviewer laughing] -Straight up.
It was really the actual transformation of Cash Money.
translation.ko: 캐시 머니가 확 변하게 된 시기였어요

translation.en: They let all the other artists go. I mean, everybody.
translation.ko: 다른 모든 아티스트들을 내보냈죠 진짜로 모두요

translation.en: The room went from a room full of people
to five or six people,
and that's including the producer, Baby, Slim, and the groups.
The fingers were just pointing at,
"Now y'all gotta do it."
[Mannie Fresh] The whole concept of how MCs worked off each other,
like back in the G.
That was my thought on how I was gonna work The Hot Boys.
A modern day Furious Five.
At the time, it was the leather thing
that they did, or whatever, but it was the uniform.
Everybody had the same thing on.
Everybody moved as one.
It was the bandana, the long white Ts.
translation.ko: 두건을 두르고 큰 흰 티셔츠를 입었죠

translation.en: [Juvenile] Damn, dawg. It's the Furious Five redub.
I'm Melle Mel in there.
They're jealous.
I can't be nobody else but Melle Mel.
translation.ko: 그런데 누가 봐도 내가 멜레 멜이잖아

translation.en: [Juvenile] Damn, I didn't know that's how he saw that.
The look is the Magnolia.
Before we even got around, did anything with Cash Money,
translation.ko: 캐시 머니랑 작업을 하기도 전에 저희는

translation.en: we were wearing T-shirts, Girbauds and Reeboks.
We got packs of T-shirts, and packs of rags, and boxes of soldiers.
translation.ko: 티셔츠, 바지 밀리터리 룩 다 있죠

translation.en: Man, we would show up to an event,
and they'd see us earlier that day,
and they all think we had the same clothes on,
translation.ko: 다 똑같이 입었다고 생각할 거 아니에요

translation.en: "Yo man, that's bad. We gotta change our wardrobe."
[Juvenile] We are Hot Boys.
We fires that can't be put out.
translation.ko: 절대 끌 수 없는 불과 같죠

translation.en: You could call every fire engine truck in the United States
and let 'em wet us down,
but we still gonna burn.
We still gonna burn.
It was undeniable, because all of them were dope artists.
translation.ko: 그건 부인할 수 없어요 다들 엄청난 아티스트에

translation.en: Dope rappers, dope lyricists,
and you had the sound that Mannie Fresh had introduced,
which was bounce, but with a twist.
You know, you just wanna get rowdy with it.
And, that resonated everywhere.
People liked that raunchy sound, that "let's get wild" sound.
translation.ko: 그런 시끄러운 사운드를 사람들이 좋아했어요 '놀아볼까' 하는 그런 사운드요

translation.en: [M$. Tee] They did a big impact with The Hot Boys.
Everybody wanted to be like them,
with the white T-shirts, and the Girbauds on.
Everybody with the do-rag on.
Nobody was putting no suits on.
They did so much independently. I mean, like, a lot.
translation.ko: 그들만의 독자적인 길을 갔죠 정말로 독보적이었어요

translation.en: But, when you selling a lot on your own, record companies start looking at that.
translation.ko: 앨범을 많이 판매할 수록 회사들의 이목이 쏠리죠

translation.en: [Juvenile] That whole record deal with Universal,
it was a shock to the music industry.
I feel like they didn't understand
translation.ko: 우리가 앨범을 그렇게 많이 낼 거라고

translation.en: that we were gonna put out a decent amount of albums.
The quality of the sound.
Like, they didn't know, really, like
"Who are these cats?
What did they do to get 30 million dollars?"
It was a fun time for us.
How the hell are y'all out there?
[male] Put the light on them bitches.
That's a hundred Gs, player.
You see the bling in 'em?
Get a good shot of 'em, cousin.
[Lil Ya] Cash Money was always known for a flossing label.
translation.ko: 캐시 머니는 항상 물질적인 걸 강조하고 자랑했죠

translation.en: The stunting thing came about when the big deal came,
translation.ko: 큰 계약을 따내고 나서 그런 경향이 시작됐어요

translation.en: the world knew that Baby and Slim signed and had a lot of money,
translation.ko: 베이비 앤 슬림이 계약을 따내고 돈을 벌었다는 걸 모두 알게 됐죠

translation.en: and Baby also got the opportunity to really come front line.
translation.ko: 베이비가 실제로 누구보다 앞에 설 기회를 잡기도 했어요

translation.en: Let me know everything there is to know about Cash Money.
translation.ko: 캐시 머니에 대해서 알아야 할 게 뭐가 있을까요?

translation.en: A'ight. First thing to know about us,
translation.ko: 우선 첫 번째로 알아야 할 건

translation.en: I got the rap game on lock.
You must know that first.
Can't nothing or nobody fake what we trying to do
translation.ko: 우리가 하는 거 앞으로 해나갈 것들

translation.en: and what we about to do.
Second thing is,
we got this game on our level.
Y'all understand what I'm saying?
[Mannie Fresh] Now, Cash Money is solidified.
You had BG fans,
you had Lil Wayne fans, you had Turk fans and you had Juvenile fans.
translation.ko: 릴 웨인, 터크, 주버나일 팬도 모두 모았죠

translation.en: They gave everybody a platform.
To build everybody else's career off of this,
now we really gonna break y'all down into solo artists.
Next week, we doing Juvenile's album.
translation.ko: 바로 주버나일 앨범을 그 다음 주에 작업했어요

translation.en: Cash Money had been out,
but they hadn't gotten to where No Limit was yet.
And then, when that 400 Degreez album came out,
it took over as the number one rap sound in New Orleans.
Always in the back of our minds, we was... We had to do real good on our art,
translation.ko: 항상 깊은 마음 속에서는 우리가 노 리미트를

translation.en: try to be better than No Limit.
Not saying that we were chasing them.
They were the ones in the game.
Like, if you gonna beat anybody in the music game,
or compete with anybody coming from New Orleans,
translation.ko: 성공하고 싶다면 뉴올리언스에서는 적어도 노 리미트 수준에는

translation.en: you gotta at least be close
to where No Limit at.
We went from here, to here,
and I knew, you gotta follow up.
Especially on a national album.
At the time, I really felt like if anybody was gonna make a bounce record,
translation.ko: 만약에 누군가 바운스 음반을 낸다고 하면 누구나 이걸

translation.en: and make everybody like it and break it to the world,
translation.ko: 좋아하고 세상에 내놓을 수 있어야 한다 생각했어요

translation.en: it was going to be me.
That was my focus.
I was like, "Just gimme a real fast beat and let me go."
[Mannie Fresh] The beat was a bounce beat,
but what made "Back That Azz Up" different was it had structure to it.
translation.ko: '백 댓 애즈 업'의 차별점은 무엇보다 구조에 있어요

translation.en: It had a chorus, it had a bridge.
I started incorporating more music to these beats.
The top part of it was classical music.
At that moment, hip-hop was going crazy,
because nobody was doing where the song broke down,
translation.ko: 그런 음악을 아무도 안 했거든요 음악을 틀고

translation.en: and there was this part for these girls to go nuts.
[Mannie Fresh] All of that won it over.
It crossed over to both worlds.
I was like, "Holy shit."
[Big Freedia] "Back That Azz Up" was rapping over more of a bounce beat.
translation.ko: '백 댓 애즈 업'은 바운스 비트에 랩을 한 건데

translation.en: Like, we got one that's gonna put the limelight on New Orleans,
and repping the sound of New Orleans.
translation.ko: 뉴올리언스의 사운드에 쏠릴 거란 걸 알았죠

translation.en: [DJ Jimi] "Back That Azz Up" showed them twerking, you know.
They took it out. They took it more nationwide.
From it being local to now everybody knew about this.
translation.ko: 원래는 지역에서만 공유되던 게 이제 누구나 아는 게 된 거예요

translation.en: [M$. Tee] When Juvie came through, it was something fresh,
translation.ko: 주버나일이 앨범을 냈을 때 굉장히 신선했어요

translation.en: it was something new, it was something that nobody else was doing.
translation.ko: 어느 누구도 그런 시도는 하지 않았거든요

translation.en: He just had an original vibe.
It was awesome!
I'm a girl, nigga, and I went and bought that fucking CD!
translation.ko: 난 여자인데도 CD 샀으니 말 다 했지

translation.en: [Mannie Fresh] Everything after that
was certified platinum record from Cash Money.
translation.ko: 내는 앨범은 내는 족족 플래티넘이 됐어요

translation.en: It's one of the longest lasting labels that's been around.
translation.ko: 가장 오래 지켜온 레이블 중에 하나죠

translation.en: [Master P] That's their legacy.
I'm proud of them. I'm happy for them that they went on their own.
I think it was a good time for New Orleans,
so where we were the first and they came right behind us.
translation.ko: 우리가 먼저 시작하고 그 친구들이 나중에 시작했는데

translation.en: It showed the world what we were about,
translation.ko: 우리가 어떤 사람들인지 이 세상에 똑똑히

translation.en: what we stood for,
the pain, the struggle, the hustle.
translation.ko: 우리의 아픔, 힘든 생활 노력 등을 보여줬고

translation.en: It represented the culture.
[narrator] Luke Records, Rap-A-Lot, LaFace.
translation.ko: 루크 레코드, 랩 어 랏 라페이스까지...

translation.en: Until New Orleans came along,
these were the labels that defined the South,
but the countless platinum plaques
that No Limit and Cash Money stacked were unparalleled.
